qas.question: What degree does not include simple formulas for cubic and quatric equations?
What concept is associated with the solvability of polynomials?
What are used to express the solutions of polynomials?
What degree must it be lower than to have simple formulas?
What give criterion for abstract properties?
Which group cannot be expressed using radicals?
What is an example of a complex operation?
What do cubic and quartic equations not have?

context: <b6_0>Exchanging "+" and "−"<b6_0/> in the expression, i.e. permuting the two solutions of the equation can be viewed as a <b7_0>(very simple) group operation<b7_0/>. Similar formulae are known for cubic and quartic equations, but do not exist in general for <a0_0><b3_0>degree 5<b3_0/> and higher<a0_0/>. <a1_0>Abstract properties of <b5_0>Galois groups<b5_0/><a1_0/> associated with polynomials (in particular their solvability) give a criterion for <b4_0>polynomials<b4_0/> that have all their solutions expressible by <a2_0>radicals<a2_0/>, i.e. solutions expressible using solely addition, multiplication, and roots similar to the formula above.
